 Or education impacting the quality of religion. See, the correlation could mean something different that you're assuming. We only know they might be related; we don't know in what way.
 
 But I suspect what's really happening here, is that this discrepancy could more likely be explained in terms of rural versus city. Rural areas have less local tax funds for good schools, and therefore are naturally not going to have the resources that large-city schools have. Note that the 5 states listed are all very "rural" type states with no major cities (like L.A., Atlanta, Chicago, etc.) There is New Orleans, but the rural areas of Louisiana are among some of the poorest in the country, so it sort of off-sets there. So the education status of these states may not even have anything to do whatsoever with the fact there are very 'religious states'. These stats just don't prove anything.

 More money does not equate to better education. I have a sister who's a public school teacher and I went to a private college prep highschool. Money does not make the difference most of the time. It's the kids themselves and the parents. You can have the best funded education system but if your kids and your parents don't care, it doesn't matter how well funded you are. I have friend who went to my school (one to the top 20 prep in the country) who then went to community college because they did not put the time and effort into getting an education. It is a big mistake to believe that throwing money at things will always make them better. And I have friends who went to terribly funded public who are very intelligent and very educated because they put the work in.

 I never said, nor do I believe that, as you clumsily put, "religion equates to ignorance." I was merely noting the statistical association between amount of education (not intelligence) and religiosity. It has repeatedly been demonstrated to be an inverse relationship. That relationship exists outside of any opinions you or I have. 
 
 Do you know what a meta-analysis is? That study attempted to look at EVERY study ever done; that is why there are some that date to the 20's. As the author states, the methodology of many of the studies is flawed or underpowered. That is the point of a meta-analysis. Admittedly, there are limitations to metaanalyses as well. 
 
 In any event, there are some fairly straightforward (and recent, and peer-reviewed, they were given) studies that show that religiosity among scientists, at least, is less than the general population. There is a substantial difference. One can only speculate, for now, the reason for that difference. 
 
 I drew no conclusions from these findings. You seem to have, as you've got your panties in a knot over them. You got bent out of shape over a single word, "eminent". I don't know how it was defined in the study, but I am sure it was operationalized.

Actually, I think that he summarized his statistics from several studies that have been done over the years.
 
When pressed for a link to his statistics, he claimed that it's an independant study he did himself.
So your assertion is that we should take what you say as truth, without support, but reject the results of his research?
 
So what sources did he use to come up with these numbers.
I suspect that he used several well known polls, including Gallup.
 
Did he survey an equal, yet representative sample number of people in each State in order to determine which States were most religious?
I think that it is more likely that he used sources that did so. You see, his study was not of the population, but of various scientific surveys of the population.
 
 For example, Gallup has found that a typical creationist is female (54% of females and only 40% of males), Southern (54% in the south, 47%, 45%, and 40% in the Midwest, West, and East, respectively), and uneducated (64% have less than high school education, 57% of high school graduates, 44% with some college, and 31% of college graduates). The above numbers are combined results from Gallup Polls from 1991, 1993, and 1997. The numbers have been much the same since. Other findings of the Gallup Polls were that creationists were more likely to be manual laborers than blue collar or white collar workers. Creationists also tended to be less affluent, and more rural. Gallup doesn't make any causal connection between his statistics, and, of course, occupation, affluence, and living conditions are probably results of education rather than religious beliefs.

 No, sorry Neanderthal. It's really your own responsibility to prove your points here, and state your own case with proof. I did a Google search (though not anything real in-depth) and didn't see much of anything. I'm not saying you're wrong here. I'm just saying we don't know. No conclusions can be ascertained from something we can't even validate. However, I do think it's the sort of post that rings the bell of anyone who wants to see religion painted badly, and there are definitely some people here who all but salivate over things like that. No doubt, there are some here who would LOVE to prove anything negative about religion.
 
 If you got the graph from a book, and it was any decent book or textbook whatsoever, there should have been some sort of indication SOMEWHERE of the source. A footnote, endnote, or anything. If not, then it's worthless anyway to begin with, IMO. And you were pretty specific in the details from the graph, so one can only assume you either HAVE the book (in which case you could reveal the title and author and check for citations) or at least spent a good deal of time with it gleaning information that specific. It seems pretty unlikely you'd remember such specific details from memory (from "a few years ago") as the stats you gave. So surely you can understand that something isn't really adding up here.

A simple google for religiosity by state brought up this, which suggests that the richer you are, the less religious.
 That explains televangelists. ;) 
 
 http://www.stat.columbia.edu/~cook/movabletype/archives/2007/11/religiosity_and.html
I made the graph. Probably used InDesign. I don't have sources, sorry. But like I said, you can find this information anywhere now.
